sisse 26-Jan-18 04:07 AM
📍
=> Newbies and amateurs look at the ultimate tick and call to the universe a move that the whole grail is in that reversal in the 1 minute candle you saw the signal ... experience traders just laugh at the 1 thousand failures before that ultimate tick was the actual ultimate tick ... (edited)
So
lets dig into more details
3‚É£
Macro Direction
You want to establish your macro direction whatever your TF (edited)
As a general rule of thumb and for those new in OTM a healthy standard to be in sync with proper market moves:
=> Long Term (LT): Month to Quarters
=> Mid Term (MT): Weeks to Months
=> Short Term (ST): Days to Weeks
=> News Flows / Intraday micro trades: Hours to Days
📍 A complete Swing (wave or whatever you want to call it) can last as long as 4 or 5 years in a LT or in the case of a ST swing as short as a couple of days
📍
I am pointing this out so you have a clear idea for scoping TIMING in your TRADES (more on that later)
We just got a few traders this week trying to sell the top in for a LT swing that could pan out in 2020!!!!
so go figure it wont work as nobody will hold 3 years

So the concept of a swing is fairly simple

* A Support* = The core tiny levels around the formation which is the core of the Support or Resistance e
A Support Zone = the Area between the open and close of the swing and the ultimate low

1‚É£
sisse 28-Jan-18 11:48 PM
* A Basic Price Algorithm*
This is the most basic flow we can find in any market and any Timeframe:
=> Support/Resistance => Break => Retrace => Continuation => => Support/Resistance => Break => Retrace => Continuation ...... => Support/Resistance => Failure => => Support/Resistance => Break => Retrace ..... (edited)
in a endless loop
=> with that simple but powerful concept you could be 90% of the time in sync with the market.
You maybe wrong in your trade but you shouldn't be lost in translation of what is going on....
e.g.
Failure = In the last chart price bread down you may decide to go short on the retrace to last break ....and suddenly price reverses and keep going up up up (edited)
Continuation = exactly what happened in the last chart: Break => Retrace => Continuation
==
Last time our TA LAB was calling / spotting the end of a retrace leg in the current direction and the start of the continuation leg
This is the after the fact and current direction chart:
The end of second line/arrow red and the begging of the third line were last TA. Now we are here
=> Again like last time there is very little to see to start with:
=> We are in a clear downtrend (edited)
sisse 29-Jan-18 12:00 AM
=> We already broke down and we are in the continuation leg
📍
The challenge for this TA LAB is to determine and trade if this leg down is over or it will continue to go down
Thats in a nutshell is all the calls we are going to make . (edited)
2‚É£
Before we get into deeper TA, here we make a coupe of very importants 📌
=> For those new around and coming from micro timeframes they my struggle to digest these concepts at the beginning.
📍 Timing
Our macro direction chart is over a year of data (edited)
Our current direction and last swing took around 3 months to fully pan out (edited)
Meaning you need to understand we are going to be calling a few inner legs in between with the objective of calling the continuation of this swing' or the end of this leg
🔑 MARKETS don‚Äôt move out of the blue in the middle of nowhere
without a FA reason behind
🔑 Market trade expectations first and facts later
üíØ 2
If you understand these 2 premises you will be a thousand miles ahead of most.
Why>?
Because you wont be chasing ghosts on the middle of nowhere, neither have false expectations on when to hold, when to trade and when to walk away...
üëç 2
3‚É£
We can introduce the next set of TA concepts only when we have a real reason to introduce them, not before.
🔑 Every time you introduce an Indicator (any) you have to ask yourself the ‚ùì Why? What I am gaining? What I am losing? can i use pure Price Analysis to reach the same point? if not ...only then you can introduce a fresh TA.
=> Lets start with the last TA call:

📍 Most of you have read one million times already so we are going to go quickly and deeper:
We know our macro direction is down

Mapping your trade
=> We don't need to introduce a new indicator right now, but we need to find a way to standardise Price Analysis so you can quickly and consistently apply it everywhere.
How do we do that ?
4‚É£
ABC and abc
=> We are going to establish a set of parameters to understand swings (we covered swing non the last TA LAB here)
How do we start?
Well lets choose the last retraceleg and build forward until we reach the right of the chart (the live part of the chart)
📍 identify the last swing down before the retrace
sisse 29-Jan-18 12:26 AM
Yes after the fact it doest matter
📍 * Plot a reference line "A" on the last broken Support *
once you have that line
📍 *Look back the last Swing High before that Line A Support and mark the Resistance with B *
If price break above that B
📍 We call that a *ABC REVERSAL / SWING REVERSAL formation *
A quick note here
For those sharp enough you can see we have E (extension in the B):
That is our Reversal ABC
=> This reversal formation is important very important why:
🔑 It allow you to mark when a leg/swing/wave is officially over. When a retrace/pullback starts and end. When a continuation leg starts / end
For later when we introduce other indicators or lines like FIBS. This extremely powerful concept will allow you to plot consistently the 'right' ranges instead of chart fitting your ranges until some fit your lines...
📍 We can now apply this to the next ABC reversal :
Same as before
Check the last Swing High Break
sisse 29-Jan-18 12:40 AM
=> Mark A
=> Check the last Swing low in this case and mark B in Support
It should be fairly simple now to recognise the e (extensions)
and line B extended a bit lower
=> Break, retrace to break and ...down we go in the Continuation leg
Pay attention that we haven't done anything beyond some simple price analysis so far

Ok, I'm jumping in, not sure about it though, hope some others will jump in too, to be spanked with me.

The two valid ABC reversals allow us to plot a consistent fib : hence, we can notice we extended the move as far as the 161.8% extension (88.4x). As long as we don't have a valid ABC reversal to the upside (it's true we have the sketch of such an ABC reversal here, but far from being triggered, and that could be, moreover, cancelled by the break of the SL at 88.4x), the rule is to play the fibs extensions to the downside on this TF (D1). Hence, next major target is the 261.8% fib extension (84.32).

HOWEVER, here, for the round 2, we are tracking the next micro ST flow which coincide with the Monthly close. There is a LT break in play at 91.0x (ext).

So, on one hand, bulls might want to prevent this and try to strike back, aiming the 91.0x area to avoid the break with a natural stop at the low (88.4x) and an intermediate target at the A (90.5x), and with an entry a tick above last high (entry stp 89.6x).
On the other hand, aggressive bears might want to jump in the same area (entry lmt 89.5x) to aim the low (88.4x) and beyond (no f** clue where for the st flows) and with a stop right above the A (90.6x).

Nik 30-Jan-18 03:39 AM
does anyone have a document where the difference between ABC and abc is explained?
I have read all the documents that were posted in the RUT channel and noticed the abc formations but i didn't find an explaination of them
I also found out that sometimes an A or B line is drawn on the open/close of a candle and sometimes on the high or low.
Is there a reason for it?
SM 30-Jan-18 03:51 AM
Well I'll try to explain but i'm not the best one to do that so a correction might be in order. We mark with A (caps) the first swing low of the downtrend (like a little bit above in pa1ntomaker charts) and B with the firs swing high. Then if the trend continues we use small letters or add an ' or an 1..2..3.. Now with that break of the B you can play against the bears all the way up to the break out point (maybe even higher) (edited)
personally I take the whole wick of the candle as an A or a B. Take it as a zone not as an precise point (price) I think that drawing an A or a B on the open/close of the candles is wrong. it must be at the top of the wick (or in my case the entire wick of the candle) {this is a personal opinion it might be wrong} (edited)
I'm pretty sure that it's better to use the wick as an A or B cuz the variation of the price with different brokers. it's seems a safer way to determin if the B is broken
hope it helps and I did not embarrassed myself much as I am not the best around here to explain all this

@Replicant right where you put that x is where I would say a SL is confirmed. Not before it. So I would put A at that time (not earlier) right where you got it or at the LL where your first SL mark is. Then I would look for a breach/break of A from there forward. Multitasking a candle like that (It's my SH and part of my SL in my example there) always makes me think I'm chartfitting or more exactly, trying to see the smaller tf through the bigger tf chart. Either way, because of that I would be looking to the zone between the B you got there and the B I just said I'd be looking at rather than the hardline level B. My 2 cents are probably hardly worth one cent on this because I've had the same confusion being discussed here many times. (edited)

=> We have discussed Swings, Ranges and some core price concepts but why do we want to introduce something else in the analysis ?
Remember every time we introduce a new TA we have to ask ourselves why? what do we gain ? what do we lose ?
Traders want to introduce other indicators in this case lines because they want to gauge the moves.
They want to find quantifiable areas where to find buying opportunities, take profits or place stops.
1‚É£
We are going to start with a bit of theory but it will be very practical and will build to cover all the points.
Dow Theory
A couple of centuries ago in 1882 a guy called Charles Dow and his partner Edward Jones founded Dow Jones & Company
Dow for years published his ideas in the Wall Street Journal and are consider the founding father of technical analysis.
These same guys year later published the first stock market average of 11 stocks to determine the health of the economy ....
Probably most of you guys didn't know that these same guys are the creators of the DJi that today lost -4.3% in a massacre session. (edited)
sisse 06-Feb-18 03:36 AM
=> But what do we want to learn for going see far in time ?
📍 The 🔑 concept of originality in any field is not in creating something new out of the blue as most assume but in as the, concept suggest, going back to the origins
Thats why we are going so far back in
Some of this concept have pass through decades and centuries and the core notions still holds the same validity despite if you are using a super algo / quant or a chartist .or anything in between.
üëç 1
2‚É£
Any market have 3 trends
📍 A primary trend
Which is easily visualised as a tide (edited)
if the tide is high, you can see the shadows of the water getting higher and higher or the opposite when the tide is low
📍 An intermediate trend
Which is the waves that make that tide
Waves come and push the tide higher and higher. They come in a cyclical movement, sometimes they 3 in a row, sometimes one big wave, or 10 small waves, etc
📍 A smaller trend
Which are the small currents that pull the water back into the ocean after a wave has finished ...
You get the point
In simple words: what Dow was defining is
that you have LT trends that are very strong FA forces that make a TIDE
The MT trend are the waves that create the HH or LL in a high and low tide
and the ST trends are the minor pullbacks /retraces against those wave...
Ok nice so what ?
sisse 06-Feb-18 03:48 AM
📍
Well the majority of traders don't get this concept right
If you fail to recognise what move are you in and what move you are trading, you wont know if you are aiming for a major wave or if you are drowning in a tiny small pullback ...
3‚É£
* A way to gauge the moves*
So if a trend is going up as DOW was assuming and most assume in Equities.
How do you spot the a good value area to buy a retrace ?
the idea was that you want to ride the tide so evaluating an average of the bigger Industrial Stocks you will have a very good gauge of how the market and the economy is going.
This was the time before calculators or computers and etc
📍
Dow started by using a simple division of 3
=> Take the a clear meaningful low and high and dive that range in 3:
33% 66% 99% rounding to 100
📍 This is the 1st TA approach to establish retrace lines. He came to the conclusion that most of stock retraced between 33% and 66% and that was a good area to buy
while stocks that hasnt retrace at least 33% there are too early too buy and didn't represent good value
Here I invite and you will be surprise
to use a simple Down theory and split the range in 3: no more no less
Here the 1st chart:
Yes as you would expect
sisse 06-Feb-18 03:59 AM
we take those meaningful lows and highs
and as can clearly see
sisse 06-Feb-18 04:00 AM
that the first retrace spot perfectly in the 33% retrace
but as Dow predicted is probably not a good time
and price retraces later above 33% and below 66% which is a good are according to DOW to sell (in this case)
...and there you have it, a simple system that will prolly work and have better results than 80% of the crap systems around the retails world ...
4‚É£
We are not going to review the whole process of how TA evolved from this but a large majority of indicators lines and algos have its roots in this very very basic principles.
=> ‚è©
This theory evolved and it was improve, complicate and destroy to some extend by some smart ass traders that start using fibonacci numbers
Fib numbers are nor related to trading but it come form maths and nature ...but for the purpose of this conversation
the fibs theorist said the actual numbers are 61.8% and 38.2%
instead of 66% and 33%%
which as you can see in our case
it wont change much the end result
sure the 38.2% doesnt leave us any doubt in this case that it was too early to load
and the entry is +/- in the same area
5‚É£
As you can expect, Gann and other theorist and every single math theory started to get apply to trading and charts (edited)
Some of the LT chart were so LT (remember this is the time of no day trading with chart update live ....we are talking about 1900!!!)
sisse 06-Feb-18 04:11 AM
that although visually the numbers fibs (or dow) look very good
in reality waiting 15 years to pan out or the large ranges in between the line were just too big ...
so the natural reaction was well
=> Well if all retraces are around 38.2 / 61.8 or 33% 66% why not include a very simple measure that is easy to viusaize and calculate
📍 50% line (edited)
and of course it made sense
but that didn't really help gauging the last gap in between the range until prices move to 50%
and more importantly ...what happens when price is already on the way back to 50% ??? how do you jump in
📍 and the answer was simple if we have 50% why not 25% and 75% (edited)
üòÑ 1
that come from Gann * and etc while the Fib guys said right let use *fib numbers instead what about 23.6% and 78.4% and etc (edited)
and thats how we ended up with this
which is Standard Fibonacci default retrace that comes in any charting platform
6‚É£
But things evolved and advanced calculations were possible and was easier to have data
The 2 modern groups that came from TA lines in general come from two very influential schools (if you can call that in tA)
📍 One was Murray that was a derivate from Gann that extends further the idea of plotting the range (edited)
in 1/8
why 1/8 well for a lot of math reasons...for those in music and notes they will understand better but the point was simple
sisse 06-Feb-18 04:21 AM
divide a range in 1/8
But they went even further
=> As any trader will know, all these sounds fantastic and easy
but
📌
Defining the right highs and lows* started to get more complex and too subjective (edited)
Sure in a yearly DJI updated manually left some but little room of interpretations
but suddenly a daily chart in 1000 different Futures and Stocks and etc
where liquidity was not that clear
started to leave huge doubts: Is this the hig ‚ùì was that the low ‚ùì or it was that over here ‚ùì
This questions are the decades and decades later and with all powerful computers and the crux of a lot of retail traders are in these exact same questions
So what did they do? (edited)
📍 When the manage to establish a lookup back range (edited)
calculate on every candle (i think in 64 candles original...64 for some square of 8 math reason) (edited)
so if the new candle didn;t break the range
the last 64 bars lookup period will keep the high and low
but if the bar went outside it will recalculate the new range and split in 8....
those who still use classical Murray will know better**
📍 The second thing they went further
is to try to gauge the moves and reversal
sisse 06-Feb-18 04:31 AM
so they define if price move inside of the 1/5 and 1/3 *Which is +/- the same as fibs and dow) is the normal area if it goes to 2/8 is the extreme /and so for
we are not going to cover this here
but you get the point
7‚É£
But probably the most influential TA in terms of lines and etc
comes from Elliot Wave
📍 These guys tried to solved the same problems but from a different perspective/
📍 Instead of gauging a range in a static range they introduced the idea of waves
So price moves in waves and there is not only 3 TFimeframes as Dow suggested but a lot (with a lot of names)
EW theory is irrelevant here
📍 Among other things they started defined how the structure of the waves work (edited)
So waves moves in set of 5 ...expansive waves, retraces in 3 waves and etc (edited)
in a perpetual cycle
between all TFs
📍 But also they introducing important ideas on how to gauge retraces/pullbacks and expansion/extensions of the waves in a more meaningful way
8‚É£
The modern modern derivates from those schools are millions
From those retailchartist with funny animal names (crabs, bats etc) that are nothing more than simple EW legs simplified.
To more complex and use it everyday algorithmic scales (edited)
sisse 06-Feb-18 04:40 AM
here i make a break as i know some of you guys come from FF and you know about mofus
we will talk in more detail later
but mofus in the context of all the history background they are noting more than a simple standard deviation applied to a level (in this case mostly the 50% line) that are part of basic algorithmic flows in FX and some other markets
Basically the validity of astd deviation is a basic principle in any algorithmic system, but a std deviation in itself doesn't do anything or explain anything beyond what all the other theories above do or don't ...
We'll talk details later on this ...
📍
I know these was a rathe loooong historical and theoretical background
But I honestly think most don't have even the sightless clue of why and how to use it properly. The just sit and shot to see what sticks.

the 🔑 is knowing where and how to to look for those answers
...and like in everything else in trading ...there are not 100% answer for all problems. Some of the flaws are just part of the cost of doing business so as long as you apply proper risk reward and know what are you doing Lines can magic lines can be incorporated successfully in TA ...

sisse 07-Feb-18 03:03 AM
The main problem with magic lines including the real big ones like fibs and etc is that most of the people that try to use them don't have a clue why and how to use it consistently. (edited)
So lets start v. quickly listing the main problems with magic lines and then we can see the positive side before establishing some parameters for proper use
=> Promote overtrading. (edited)
=> Chart fitting
=> They stop searching for the Holy Grail and start the endless loop of searching for the right Swings high and lows
=> They create more chaos than help if not use properly (edited)
=> 80% of the retail traders around don't have a clue how to use them properly and have zero knowledge of algorithmic trading and grids (edited)
=> They blur charts making you focus in the could shoulda have been winners while making it very difficult to spot the next one coming ... (edited)
...and the list go for a few dozen more points ...
1‚É£
Lets start with mofus but these points apply to most if not all magic lines (edited)
A beautiful example
So what the big deal
=> Mofus are absolutely nothing special
As we mentioned yesterday a lot of maths and traders on the last centuries have tried to define ranges
so we say the 33% the 38.2% the Murray the Ganns and etc etc
=> Mofus which is a name coined in FF by gatorinla is simple
a Standard deviationapplied to a level very commonly use in FX algorithmic systems to normalise the noise around a level
üíØ 2
yes yes a mouthful
sisse 07-Feb-18 03:12 AM
basically
if you have a level, any level, you create a noise range around there in which the level enters in play
in this particular case its applied to a 50%
which is as we all know a common retrace area in almost all systems using lines
so basically
those 44.1% / 55.9% are not some magic numbers from some magic land (edited)
but they are calculated based on a series of statistical factors that define the level of noise in a distribution (not for this discussion .)
So in some more illiquid or more volatile markets that noise zone can be wider or in more liquid and less volatile markets can be narrower.
📍 (edited)
Here we are are just defined why and where those levels come form not how to use them or when to plot it right now. (edited)
2‚É£
As you can expect the logic behind how they work is rather simple
here is a real example right now on the last swing in the
Keep in mind that we are just talking about how they are use now how and why and when to plot those lines (we'll get there in a minute)
This is a clean example of the noise zone in play (edited)
this is a very basic case of how lines (any line works)
as you can see if you are betting on a 50% retrace
you can clearly see the noise range allow you to see that the level is not taken to the downside even if apparently is taken the 50%
sisse 07-Feb-18 03:22 AM
Also pay attention how the first attempt (green line) fails to escape the range while in the second green circle it break the range
giving screaming signals that the level is going to hold and a bounce is on this way ....
so far nothing new
this applies to all lines
3‚É£
Here is were things start getting more interesting and complicate
So well all nice and all that but what else do we gain doing all this
Well the answer is simple
Mofus and all other lines try to go a step beyond
and try to forecast where the move will extend (edited)
In the case of EW and Fibs the explanation are extensive and complex
In the case of Mofus is more anecdotical based on hope some times, "just in case' in others" and in trial and error in others (edited)
A quick 📌

The main problem Fib and Mofus and Line traders have* is they don't HAVE a clue (generalising of course and not all) of the context of the legs
=> They don't know why a leg is going/could/sohuld to extend to 150% or 200%
and which ones not
=> The don't understand the difference between a expansion leg and retrace leg
üëç 5
=> The dont know how to recognise a measured move (before it happens of course) with a value testing move
=> They don't realise that market unfold in waves that have different characteristic depending on the range they are in play (edited)
üîë 3
All these questions are where the REAL TA is
not in plotting 100 lines on every second swings in every second timeframe to see what it fits
so ending up with the first chart we stared
sisse 07-Feb-18 04:42 AM
📌
This extension wave is the first and most basic wave to understand in TA analysis
Is a simple Retrace Leg
=> For those from #technicals and Gourmetrader....
" Price moves in waves ...."
This, as bearish and crazy as it looks, is a retrace leg in an uptrend (edited)
The simplest of the legs in TA (edited)
some call it (EW and etc) an *ABC retrace * (we are not going to use that because we have other ABC definitions ) (edited)
=> A simple Retrace leg is compose in 2 main parts
📍 The break pullback swing (A...we'll use other naming to avoid confusion later) (edited)
and
📍 and the momentum swing (B...) (edited)
Almost every single retrace in trend (except one which is the change of trend)
has this basic characteristic
You may miss the break out swing retrace
but you can't miss the momentum swing
📌
Dumb money is chasing crumbs on every mofus or fibs or whatever....This is call trading TA instead of trading markets (edited)
sisse 07-Feb-18 04:51 AM
While Smart money and proper algorithmic system use these tools as tools to grab the directional swings (edited)
=> Don't trade the techs, trade the markets
üîë 6
Here with this very powerful concept, we introduce for the first time in OTM advanced TA that goes beyond the triggers and basic talk. (edited)
So
answering the original question
=> We trade this leg because we are aiming to trade the momentum swing leg in this retrace of the uptrend
We can use a mofu as reference here
but price action *ALWAYS * prevail over any magic line
WE are looking for a retrace to the 50% area (edited)
not because magic lines tell us that
is because the rejection of the last swing high is pointing us (yellow lines)to look for entries around there
therefore a 50% or a mofu is perfect and expect there
Finally and without showing you the left of the chart (edited)
the 150% is a perfect retrace target in a momentum swing in a retrace (edited)
but as you expect ...
there is a majot TA support (hidden on the chart) on the left
...
I hope it helps and open new ideas of where to aim in TA
instead of focusing in every single trigger, line and swing to trade without knowing where and why ....

How about also trying out a novel idea and approach a training lab from the opposite direction, ie reversing the system of talking through the training labs afterwards but rather beforehand in advance of events. And you'll always have traders eg wishing to enter a retrace against the trend to try and milk a few sneaky pips so no matter what sisse's wise analysis might be I'd say there's enough traders here who'd still trust their instincts to follow & defend their own calls.
I'm coming here from the angle of finding the optimal learning experience and not sure how this would realistically work with proper points competitions or live trader lab cash calls, but no reason why not to try it out there either. There would then be an almost group consensus in advance as to what are the most likely scenarios that could play out in a trade and to therefore also decide on all the TP's STP's etc too. This of course has the bi-product of allowing many more to participate in the competition calling process and preparing them better for calling their own competitions in the future.

sisse 08-Feb-18 12:22 AM
@Fadhl
: (1) can we consider the ABCD Pattern (AB=CD) reflects very well this concept and hence it applies only in retrace?

AB = CD (meaning a 100% extension) in my books wont be usual (or not at all) retrace leg. A perfect symmetric extension is more common in the first leg with the trend.
(2) the Equities drop is a retrace; therefore can we expect the part B of it: the momentum swing?
Depends what leg you are referring too. This is a tricky question because the moves were massive. I mean rally massive.
In general NO in the ST (edited)
We are already deep into the momentum leg right now in the MT and LT. In the ST we were in the momentum leg as well but obviously it ended after the last 2 days crazy moves. (edited)
The main problem is that explosive moves like this cover a ST/MT/LT in one sweep. (edited)
Big problem when we have very unhealthy rallies like the last year in Equities. Markets went overboard instead of more natural ebb and flow. So buying blindly without caring about value or price discovery, always end like that....in a very unhealthy and damaging clean sweep. (edited)
So answering your question:
We mentioned in #market-talk yesterday. The bond moves have unlocked the TAX CUT Expectations leg break out which from a FA perspective will be the best value area since the Tax cuts are expected to have zero impact in the real economy in the MT and LT (actually even negative from next year onwards via fiscal side). (edited)
=> From a TA point of view more relevant to this channel, the* momentum leg was overflown* and covered pretty much completely by the initial break down leg. ....so the 'momentum wave will probably end up being a 'tiny' move away from yesterday lows in the MT. (edited)
=> The other alternative is a full blown reversal and a new trend down ...although a real possibility from a strictly TA point of view given the structure of the last 10 year move, from a FA side seem very very very locked for now and will imply a major slowdown in the US economy ...not in the cards... (edited)

sisse 15-Feb-18 04:58 AM
I want to wrap up here with a concepts we mentioned in #technicals and in the previuos TA LAB
that I think is very important to retake (we will cover these notions in the next TA LAbS)
📍
🔑 The Natural Stop , The natural TARGET
I am highlighting these concepts because I know a couple of traders here that got burnt on the trade
sisse 15-Feb-18 05:00 AM
being right all along but losing money one of the worst and most painful sins in trading
Some traders traded to the long side a bit early
inside of the inside candle
The problems (apart from being extremely overleveraged or undercapitalise) is on very poor risk management
📍
One of the simplest and easy ways to start understanding risk management
is first before you even start looking for entries or etc
is define where is your natural stop
in this case the natural stop is a very simple as we are in a very sharp uptrend
📍 If you know that your natural stop is below that swing
First this doesnt mean 1 tick below the swing
it jsut means below the swing
Second if for whatever reason your trading system is flashing buys above
like in the example inside of the inside range
=> Measure the space between the Natural Stop and your potential area of entry (edited)
=> Adjust your size accordingly so you can withstand all the drawdown as low as the natural stop
=> if the distance between your potential entry and the natural stop is larger that the distance between your potential entry and the natural target:
🛑 Stop right there
=> There is absolutely nothing see or do. just drop / pass the trade is not worth it.
sisse 15-Feb-18 05:11 AM
Even if its the most amazing perfect flawless setup in your system and even if you reduce your size to 1 penny a pip ....
Is not worth it !!!
=> To wrap up
Especially for those who got burnt earlier trading directly
🔑 start introducing and spending more time in risk management and less time in TA setups and triggers (edited)
üíØ 1
🔑 Start using price based TA to help you quickly gauge potential risk and evaluate R:R before you commit to a trade.

5‚É£
Now we have a clear ABC reversal (edited)
We want to mark the 2 areas as very important in our TA chart
These 2 areas over here have very important implications deepening on the context
🔑
=> If this swing we are seeing is a Swing with the Trend / Expansive Wave (edited)
📌 Area B * (this is the general case, we may cover more details in others TA labs or in #technicals ) will become a 🔑 area as is the area of interest for *last break out (edited)
sisse 27-Feb-18 04:51 AM
A second 🔑
As you can see in this particular case WE haven't test that area yet !!! meaning if this were an uptrend ....that test should provide a very strong support in a retrace and more than probably is the loading area for the next swing up ....etc
=> If this swing we are seeing is a Swing against the *Trend / Retrace / Pullback wave *
📌 Area A becomes the 🔑 area for a rejection of the last swing (in this case swing low) (edited)
=> In this case, if this is a retrace/pullback leg that is your loading area of interest to fade the move if you are willing to trade
A third 🔑 in this case
=> IF this is not a retrace / pullback wave but an actual a complete Reversal of the trend (we wont cover this here) Area A is the earliest confirmation point that a new trend is forming and **Area B is the initial momentum play .....
These last 2 are complex and advanced case and obviously they appear less often as they are constrain for changes in trends...

=> As you all now markets and trends unfolds in waves
=> A trend is a group of expansion waves with a bunch of retraces/pullbacks in between.
The combination of all of them form the ebb and flow in any market. (edited)
These concepts are not new and all of you know them. We are just putting some naming on them
But I want to go deeper in this:
🔑 An expansion wave in a trend in general will always unfold in 2 swings
=> We mentioned the initial ideas on this on the last TA LAB
📍
The first swing in the wave is the initial part of the move while the second is the impulse/momentum part of the move
sisse 28-Feb-18 04:28 AM

Oscillators are very clean in trends because they are very easy to follow and spot but when we enter in consolidation a lot of people don't have a clue how to read them.
📍
=> In the chart there is the 2 ABC moves up (edited)
=> On the MACD as you all probably know we just going to introduce 2 basic premises
📌
=> We are going to say that bulls are in control every time a crossover MACD happens AND price Swing is Higher/Lower than the previous one
=> Every time the MACD cross zero we are going to call that a momentum signal thats it
so :
Those blue 1,2,3,4,5,6 are all valid ‚òë in our premise
Pay attention in 3 and 4
in the MACD 4 sure the crossover seem lo be below the MACD 3 crossover
but its irrelevant as price is still making HH
While 1,2 and 4 are also momentum crosses
There is nothing more to it
Very simple stuff and these 2 very basic premises (that applies for pretty much all oscillators) will keep keep you in the right track for very long time

5‚É£
But the beauty of oscillators is not only that keep us in the trend, keep us in the right side, give us some clues of what to expect but it also give us some hints about out natural stops and volatility expected
In genreal
📍
In a normal crossover your natural stop for reference is below the Swing of that crossover
while in a momentum crossover stops are just on the bar that that broke the range
📍 This is very important information so you don't get married with a position and more importantly to calculate your risk and position size
sisse 03-Mar-18 03:28 AM
This is call proper *trading and size position management *
most wont even grasp the basic of this....another key difference between seasoned traders and newcomers chasing triggers alone

We discussed in detail as well how to pinpoint where are we heading in a case like this
On the one hand we addd that 23.6% FIB for those with lines but we mentioned that Price will overrule any magic line in a constrained range like this.
So where were we aiming ?
=> To last Break down point
We failed by crumbs 1.245x which was extremely bad luck for bulls. A barrier got defended for ECB ...
This is our TA LAST CALL (edited)
A 📌
A hint here
Obviously, this is a tiny H4 chart for a big ECB event, trading so tight and that close to the tick put us in an unnecessary pain.
=> First, don't be a dick for a tick should have been the proper way to close the trade instead of waiting for crumbs in this case
=> But something more consistent that we have mentioned a few times in OTM
Don't trade to the tick just calculate a negative margin or error based on volaitily or by a % (like 2% or etc) to place your TP
=> *Smart money TP ahead of the consolidation and way before everybody notice price is stalling or reversing *
In this case TP on the way up not on the way down
For example if 1.245x was last break down point
Setting your TP 1.2438 /1.2440 would be more than healthy
There is nothing WRONG in leaving crumbs on the table to guarantee a safety net especially when you now a major report is in play live ...

sisse 09-Mar-18 03:44 AM
In which move should we expect the next fubar? in the current, in the next macd red ? or in the next macd blue ?

We know a fubar will appear in the impulsive swing
Therefore we were not expecting any fubars in these 2 micro legs in the chart above
=> However if we get the impulsive swing up , we will see one.
=> why / what it means ?
Very simple explanation to why fubar happens (most of the time)
=> Micro charts will start looking as they are right now for example) heavily aligned and in perfect trend to one side
a fubar will wipe / caught with the pants down all the ones in the wrong side of the direction in a sharp and violent initial move (thats why fubars most of the time appear in key reports or events like NFP or FED etc)
but this time, the move wont look back.
Leaving those married with the position holding a turd and for those laggers with entries looking at the market rally/collapse for 2 handles in a couple of sessions without any retrace for entries ...
=> In simple words and fubar appear in the impulsive waves because is a move with the right direction when most of soft an unaware hands charts are pointing to the opposite side because they can't no longer see the forest for the trees ....
